content.description: Climb a wide crack (#4) to gain a small Large. Then head up the Indian Creek style splitter for about 30 feet.
content.protection: Up to a #4 but you'll probably want several red camalots.
content.location: Look for the obvious thin hands splitter going up the middle of wall. Just up the hill and left of the slackline.

content.description: This varied climb requires a wide range of skills.Start by scambling to the top of the obvious block. Climb up the dihedral,through the chimney and into the crux hand and finger crack gaurding the anchors.   Description from Cole Fennels Rock Climbing Arkansas
content.protection: Rack to #4 camalot although i found the 5 usefull
content.location: The route is one crack to the right of WMA. Starts on a huge block leaning against the wall and goes into a nice corner crack.

content.description: Slabby with technical stemming and slopers at the bottom. Small ledges and in cut pockets throughout. The crux is low in a band of rock that is nearly featureless. Move to a big under cling.  Easy 5.9 chicken heads for the last 20 feet.  The route is dense with moss and lichen. Take a minute and do some cleaning as you climb.
content.protection: 8-9 bolts with chains and repel rings for anchors.
content.location: Go to where the most left approach trail meets the trail that runs under Confederate Cracks and Crackhouse Alley. This wall sits immediately above the two signs for Confederate Cracks and Crackhouse Alley. Royal Flush is the first route to the left of the arete.

content.description: A great view of the canyon is attained on top of this tall moderate. Jam, stem, and chimney the right side of the huge flake that forms Up Your Buttress.

climbs.name: The Mud and The Blood and the Beer

content.description: Thin fingers and lay backing up to a flared pod, continues up to two bolts and some thin face climbing to a two bolt anchor. Slightly dirty at the top, good engaging climbing more folks should hop on his one!
content.protection: Small finger sized pieces up to .75 and a few quickdraws for the 2 bolts. Fixed anchors at the top.
content.location: Route is directly to the left of "Def Jam" in the Confederate Cracks area. Route sits directly up hill from the Boulder problems "War Bonnet" and "The Crescent"

content.description: A nice pairing with Hand Grenade and a little harder. Climb the thin hands crack with tight jams and stems until the crack peters out then work up and right to shared anchors.
content.location: To the right of Classique there are two cracks. Mortar Fire is on the left.

content.description:
This is probably the hardest offwidth climb at the ranch. Start up the dirty, slabby face to gain the roof. Punch through the likely dirty/runny jams to turn the lip and enjoy better quality laybacking and climbing to the anchors.  

  The roof can be burly when wet or dirty.
content.location: Continue down (left) from the more famous WMA crack to locate the obvious roof

content.description: Start in an acute flare with a wide fist crack and squirm through the low crux. Continue up the nice jam crack past a sloping ledge into a short chimney section. The flurry of thorn bushes has been recently removed.
content.location: To the right of Classique there are two cracks. Hand Grenade is on the right.

content.description: Obvious offwidth to the right of deft jam. Beware of the loose blocks midway up.
content.protection: SR with two #4's   Bolt anchor with lowering carabiners

content.description: Climb a massive flake/buttress while stemming the main wall. Clip several bolts then make a committing slab step left to an undercling roof. Pull the roof, puzzle through a little more slab and then romp to the chains.
content.location: On the face perpendicular/left of W.M.A. and I Fought Guppies.

content.description: The route starts off hard right away with a left hand arête and mostly blank slab.  The bolts are fairly close together, but use care on the first three bolts because it's easy for something to unexpectedly blow off.  about 3/4 of the way up you get to a crimp, which feels like the biggest hold in the world.  After reaching the crimp it's significantly easier but still fun.
content.protection: (8) bolts to an anchors with fixed rap rings.
content.location: This route is immediately right of Deft Jam in the Confederate Crack area, which is part of the West Side.  Look for a obvious arête for a left hand.

content.description: Excellent splitter hand and fist crack in a shallow dihedral.  Crux is at the start, route is sustained at the grade
content.protection: Mostly #2 camalots, a few #3s and a #1 should suffice.  2 bolt anchor at top on left side wall of dihedral.  Pull rope left to avoid getting it caught   in the crack.
content.location: Continue hiking past WMA crack.  Def Jam is around the next buttress, uphill behind a boulder (a small trail splits off from the main trail right up to it).  If you encounter the sign for Crackhouse Alley, you've gone too far.  There's a 5.12 bolted arete (Door Prize) just to the right and twin finger cracks (The Mud, the Blood, and the Beer .11b)to the left.

content.description: Climb up the quickly widening fingers dihedral. Pull the awkward yet unique roof, and climb the flake to a ledge. From the ledge there is not much gear so it may feel a little run out at the top.
content.protection: Standard rack with doubles from .3-.75 BD
content.location: Follow the Confederate Cracks trail past "WMA" and follow it unil you see the obvious dihedral with a roof on the right.

content.description: Book has it as an 11a, but felt a bit harder to me. Very sustained route, crux was either mid-route or going for the anchors. Lots of fun.

Slabby route with a mix of slopers and crimps. Find good feet and trust them. Crux may be getting above the first bolt, so stick clip it. Second crux is moving from second to third bolt. Throw to slopey, but deep, hueco well above the second bolt. Climb eases up after this. Sadly, because the route is either newish or unused, it is very dirty with lichen, moss, and dirt.
content.location: Big wall above the sign for both Confederate Cracks and Crackhouse Alley at the junction of the farthest access trail coming up into the trail that runs under the west side walls.
